awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fundamental Studies on the Environmental Fate of Short-Chain and Emerging Fluorinated Alkyl Substances Using Mass-Spectrometry and Molecular Modelling
awd_abstract_narration:
The Environmental Chemical Science Program of the Chemistry Division funds Professor Diana Aga of the Chemistry Department at the University at Buffalo and Professor Scott Simpson of the Chemistry Department at St. Bonaventure University to identify per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) that contaminate the environment. These chemicals are widely used in a variety of industrial applications, including fire-fighting foams and paints, as well as in consumer products, such as food packaging and cleaning products. Residues of PFASs have emerged as significant environmental contaminants. The residues do not break down easily and accumulate in fish and wildlife over time. They are also found in drinking water sources. Exposure to these chemicals may lead to a wide range of adverse human health effects. Many important questions remain unanswered such as how PFASs are distributed in the environment, how they can be removed from drinking water sources, or how toxicities of individual components and mixtures can be measured.  The research team is identifying PFASs in the environment and developing tools to predict their mobility (e.g. how they are dispersed) and persistence (how long they stay in the environment). This project will enable the development of more accurate PFASs risk assessment models and treatment technologies. This research provides opportunities for undergraduate students from a primarily undergraduate institution to directly collaborate with graduate students at the University at Buffalo. Additionally, graduate students are hosted by scientists at the Environmental Protection Agency to gain insight on how scientific and technical information are used for developing public policies.  Summer camps for high school students from local "All-Girls" high schools are organized to promote careers in STEM.

Over 5,000 different PFASs are potentially released from the multiple formulations produced throughout the U.S.  The development of treatment strategies and complete understanding of their toxicity is hampered by the lack of standardized analytical methods and important parameters. These include the octanol-water partition coefficient for complex contaminant mixtures. Because of the varying degrees of environmental transformations, there are many unknown degradation products that have not yet been identified. Through concerted experimental and computational efforts, tools for the reliable quantification, identification, and characterization of emerging PFASs in the environment are being developed. The theoretical tools include pairing physiochemical data generated from Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Conductor like Screening Model for Real Solvents (COSMO-RS) calculations. In order to aid in the identification of unknown PFASs, the results are compared with experimentally determined liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS) retention times.  In addition, different LC-MS instruments and LC columns are being evaluated to determine efficient separation of emerging PFASs, minimize the variability of results, improve the accuracy of the LC-MS analysis, and estimate soil mobility of PFASs. The data generated from these fundamental studies are essential for developing and testing practical methods for assessing risks associated with exposure to PFASs in the environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Encompassing a group of nearly 15,000 synthetic chemicals that are widely used in industrial applications and domestic products, per- and poly-fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) have been detected throughout all environmental compartments globally. Due to the polar nature of PFAS and lack of analytical standards, current sampling and analytical methods have severely limited our ability to comprehensively identify and measure PFAS contaminants in the environment.  Furthermore, their environmental fate and biological effects are poorly understood because the physicochemical properties of many PFAS are not known.  The major goals of this project are to provide a fundamental understanding of the physicochemical properties of PFAS that affect the accuracy and sensitivity of PFAS analysis in complex environmental samples, and to develop strategies for the reliable quantification and identification of legacy and emerging PFAS.

In this project we developed sample preparation strategies to allow for quantification of known PFAS using targeted analysis, and optimized efficient workflows for non-target analysis of previously unidentified PFAS employing liquid chromatography with high-resolution mass spectrometry (LC-HRMS). We established a novel approach to identify PFAS in environmental samples based on their characteristic mass fragmentation patterns in LC-HRMS and predicted retention factors in reversed-phase LC obtained using computational tools. This approach provides higher confidence in the reporting of previously unidentified PFAS through non-targeted analysis, even in the absence of reference standards.  Based on these results, we can now provide rapid discovery of emerging PFAS in contaminated environments, such as in surface water, wastewater, and in PFAS-laden biosolids that are typically land-applied in agricultural soils. We have also calculated the octanol-water partition coefficients (Kow) and the micellular partition coefficients for over 300 PFAS, along with several new/emerging PFAS.  While Kow is generally regarded as a good metric to understand the toxicity of these compounds, micellar partition coefficients are considered to be a stronger metric because micellar systems are better representations of a cell.  The findings associated with the physicochemical properties provide information about the behavior of known and unknown (yet plausible) perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). The information obtained from this research will provide a better risk assessment and facilitate environmental management of PFAS

In addition, we showed that fluorine nuclear magnetic resonance (19F-NMR) spectroscopy, which has not been routinely applied for quantitative analysis, is capable of quantifying environmentally relevant total PFAS concentrations in wastewater and biosolids, with minimal bias from sample preparation or matrix effects. Importantly, 19F-NMR detects and quantifies ultrashort-chain PFAS that are not easily analyzed by conventional LC-HRMS methods because they are poorly retained in conventional reversed phase LC columns that are typically used in LC/MS analysis of PFAS. We have acquired and reported 19F-NMR spectra for 34 PFAS belonging to various classes (carboxylic acids, sulfonic acids, fluorotelomer sulfonic acid, methoxy-perfluoro carboxylic acids, fluorotelomer alcohols, phosphonic acids, sulfonaminated PFAS). We also developed a technique that combines experimental analysis by LC/MS/MS and 19F-NMR, with the physicochemical properties derived computationally to facilitate the identification of previously uncharacterized PFAS and their transformation products in the environment. 

Finally, we synthesized self-assembled metal-organic cages (metallacages) capable of effectively capturing 37 different PFAS species from a solution. While removal efficiency is higher for PFAS with chain lengths of seven carbons or higher, the presence of complex matrices such as untreated wastewater and groundwater samples did not reduce removal efficiency for PFAS. These tunable metallacages have potential for various applications, ranging from sample clean-up for analysis to passive continuous sample collection of emerging contaminants in aquatic systems. 

Our integrative approach has significant potential to advance our understanding of PFAS transformation pathways in the environment and in treatment systems. The results of this project, specially the derived physicochemical properties of legacy and emerging PFAS, will also impact the environmental toxicology discipline because parameters such as Log Kow and lipid partition coefficients will help predict bioaccumulation of PFAS. To avoid further development of “regrettable substitutions,” the results from our computational chemistry work could be used to guide assessment of the bioaccumulative properties of known and unknown PFAS. The methods developed from this project will facilitate analysis of known and unknown PFAS in complex environmental samples, including ultra-short chain PFAS that have not been routinely monitored despite their abundance in the environment.

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2024
Modified by: Diana S Aga
